qas.question: How are parameters chosen in a switching circuit?

answers.text: the "off" output is limited to leakage currents too small to affect connected circuitry

qas.question: What is a switching circuit trying to simulate when on?
What is a switching circuit trying to simulate when off?
How quickly does the change from open circuit to short circuit happen?
What might stop a switch from transitioning quickly?
What can help a switch work more efficiently?
What kind of circuit has the least amount of resistance?
What kind of circuit has the most resistance?

plausible_answers.text: the transition between the two states

qas.question: When is a circuit most likely to fail?

context: In a switching circuit, the idea is to simulate, as near as possible, the ideal switch having the properties of <a2_0><b7_0>open circuit<b7_0/><a2_0/> when off, <a1_0><b6_0>short circuit<b6_0/><a1_0/> when on, and an <a3_0>instantaneous<a3_0/> transition between the two states. Parameters are chosen such that <a0_0>the "off" output is limited to <b4_0>leakage currents<b4_0/> too small to affect <b5_0>connected circuitry<b5_0/><a0_0/>; the resistance of the transistor in the "on" state is too small to affect circuitry; and <b8_0>the transition between the two states<b8_0/> is fast enough not to have a detrimental effect.
